beats.label: HOOK + PROMISE
beats.narration: Should you race Rule of Three? I rated 328 gravel races on 14 dimensions. Rule of Three scored 66 out of 100. Elite tier. Here's what that actually means for your season.
beats.text_on_screen: Should You Race Rule of Three?
beats.editing_note: STATE THE PREMISE IN 8 SECONDS. Clear value prop: 'I rated 328 races. Here's where this one lands.' This is the 8-second decision window. Viewers who stay past 15s are 58% more likely to finish.
beats.psych_mechanism: Curiosity gap (specific) + IKEA effect (viewer predicts the tier before reveal).

beats.label: THE COURSE
beats.narration: Rule of Three. Emporia, Kansas (same roads as Unbound Gravel). 300 mi. 300 miles, 15 thousand ft. 95% gravel, 5% pavement. Kansas Flint Hills. same roads as Unbound. Ultra distance. Technical rating: 2/5.
beats.text_on_screen: Rule of Three | Emporia, Kansas (same roads as Unbound Gravel) | 300 mi
beats.editing_note: Let the course breathe. Show the route map, then cut to terrain-specific B-roll. This is the SETUP phase — grounding the viewer before the data analysis. Pacing: 25-40 sec cuts.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Top 8
beats.narration: Fourteen dimensions. Here's where it lands. Length. 5 out of 5. Ultra distance. Bring lights and a plan. The 300-mile distance across Emporia's roads creates sustained suffering over mixed terrain. Adventure. 5 out of 5. Type-two fun guaranteed. Type-one fun optional. Andy Chasteen's multi-surface concept emerged while testing bikes in Bentonville: "on this bike we could ride singletrack, gravel, and road all day long. Elevation. 4 out of 5. Serious elevation. Train your climbing legs. The 15,000 feet over 300 miles creates relentless climbing rather than dramatic peaks. Climate. 4 out of 5. Weather is part of the race strategy. Historical weather data shows average highs of 83°F and lows of 63°F, with a 23% chance of rain on any given day. Experience. 4 out of 5. The kind of race that reshapes your season. The multi-surface format delivers unique variety requiring equipment strategy and surface adaptation. Community. 4 out of 5. The post-race scene is half the event. Chasteen puts major decisions to Facebook votes, creating "buy-in for people who come to your event. Prestige. 3 out of 5. Respected. Not yet legendary. Chasteen draws inspiration from Burning Man culture: "It's very Burning Man-esque with costumes and quirky weirdness. Race Quality. 3 out of 5. Well-run race. Professional touches throughout. Self-supported format with unmarked courses creates pure adventure racing conditions.
beats.editing_note: PROGRESSIVE RHYTHM: start tight (15-20 sec per dimension), slow down for the most interesting scores (30-40 sec). Each score: number appears, brief pause, explanation. Avatar reacts to extreme scores (5/5 = chef_kiss, 1/5 = facepalm). RE-ENGAGEMENT at 3:00 mark: insert a surprising score reveal or a meme reaction to break the pattern.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Also Scored
beats.narration: And the rest of the scorecard. Field Depth. 3 out of 5. Good racing at every level. Value. 3 out of 5. Fair value. You get what you pay for. Expenses. 3 out of 5. Plan for a few hundred all-in. Logistics. 2 out of 5. You'll figure it out. Eventually. Technicality. 2 out of 5. Some chunky bits. Nothing catastrophic. Altitude. 1 out of 5. Sea level. Your lungs get a day off.
beats.editing_note: FAST PACING — 7 seconds per dimension. Quick-fire energy change from the deep analysis above. This is a PATTERN INTERRUPT through pacing shift.

beats.label: VERDICT
beats.narration: Verdict: Unbound Roads, 3x the Suffering. This is for riders who want the full Unbound experience without paying Unbound prices or fighting Unbound crowds. You need legitimate endurance fitness. 300 miles doesn't negotiate, and the self-supported nature means your mistakes compound quickly. Come prepared for mental warfare disguised as a bike race.
beats.editing_note: CLOSE THE MAIN LOOP. 0.5s silence before verdict. Tier badge slams in. Avatar delivers final take. DO NOT signal 'wrapping up' — maintain energy.

beats.label: ALTERNATIVES
beats.narration: If Rule of Three isn't quite right for you. Unbound 200 gives you the same roads with aid stations and more prestige. While Mid South offers similar distance with better terrain variety and actual community vibe. If you want the suffering without the Kansas wind penalty, Crusher in the Tushar delivers mountain punishment instead of prairie monotony.
beats.editing_note: Bonus value — viewers who reach this point are highly engaged. Cross-reference other videos/races.
